(40) 133rdConclusions,Minute 2.)Norway.Operations at narvik.(previous reference:W.M. (40) 133rdConclusions,Minute 5.)1. The Prime Minister gave the War Cabinet an account ofhis discussions in Paris with M. Reynaud and General Weygand.A record is contained in the Secretary's Standard File of WarCabinet Conclusions.2. The Prime Minister said that M. Reynaud took the view-that, if we lost the battle in France, a success at Narvik would beof little avail. On the other hand, if this battle were evenindeterminate, a small success at Narvik would be an enhearteningcontribution a point of view which he (the Prime Minister)regarded as good common sense.The War Cabinet took note of this statement.Aircraft.Suggestedpurchasefrom U.S.S.R.3. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs said that, onthe suggestion of the Minister for Aircraft Production, he had seenSir Stafford Cripps about the possibility of buying aircraft fromthe U.S.S.R. Sir Stafford Cripps thought it improbable that theRussians would be prepared to sell aircraft to us direct. TheChinese Ambassador had, however, suggested to Sir Stafford thatthe Russians might be induced to sell aircraft to China, who could then pass them on to us.The Chief of the Air Staff was looking into the matter; andhe (the Foreign Secretary) proposed to see the Chinese ambassador on the matter the following morning.The War Cabinet took note of this statement.Richmond Terrace, S.W. 1,May 22, 1940.
